I just noticed I hadn't directly addressed an important part of your 
last question:

On 4/26/11 4:05 PM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
> On 4/26/11 1:20 AM, Adam Brokeš wrote:

>> ...is there any automated or semiautomated way to
>> convert profiles from Heritrix 1?

We did make a *very* basic tool that, for simple settings changes to the 
default H1 order.xml, could mimic those changes into an H3 
crawler-beans.cxml. There are notes about it with the H3.0.0 Release Notes.

However, it can't handle anything not in the default configuration, and 
it doesn't even try to handle overrides.

So a manual conversion is usually necessary – and it is also probably a 
useful exercise, to become familiar with the new (reused from Spring) 
XML format and a few of the ways things are differently organized.

Most simple field settings remain, under almost-identical names (though 
the prior 'something-something' dashed names are now 
'somethingSomething' Java-properties-style camelCased). In a few cases 
the settings or classes have been renamed or moved to be more logical.

The following process should work well for the global settings:

• do a top-to-bottom review of your H1 order.xml, compared to the 
default, to refresh your idea of where you've changed the defaults, and 
for what purposes.

• work through the H3 default crawler.beans.cxml from top-to-bottom, 
changing/uncommenting those values corresponding to your H1 changes. In 
some cases you may notice interesting new settings or places where the 
new defaults make your prior customizations less necessary.

If most of your overrides fit a few simple templates – toggling 
enablement, adding blocks from a small set of common patterns, etc. – 
then you can probably reduce the many (often repetitive) override 
directories to a smaller number of 'overlay sheets' for the different 
cases. The content of these Sheets will be very specific to your global 
configuration and overrides.

Then, use one or more of the available 'SheetAssociations' to say which 
sheet(s) should apply to which target domains. (For example, if there 
are hundreds of domains that you have to crawl extra slowly, that can 
now be hundreds of associations to a single named 'crawlSlowly' sheet.) 
This step should be fairly amenable to script automation once you've 
determined the Sheet-equivalents of your overrides.

As always we're happy to help work through any difficulties that come up.

- Gordon @ IA
